comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Nobody.  But let's keep an almost lost part of our language alive.

On the other hand with the social and workplace ostracism smokers presently receive, the concept may die out altogether anyway.

comment.author: 12648435@N04
comment._content: Sydney sider here, my self and people I know use "going for a smoke-o" occasionally, so (anecdotally) I don't think it's fallen out of use, although I'm sure that the "oh" spelling of it has.

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content: I don't think it was ever called a smoke OH in the UK. What does the OH part mean?

comment.author: 53499944@N00
comment._content: Smoking helped keep flies, mosquitoes and other pests away from the face.

comment.author: 61625699@N00
comment._content: Funny, I think the photographer's cropping is a bit too much. I like all the fallen foliage in the foreground. A great shot overall. :)
